author: John Cross
title: New Chelsea boss Antonio Conte has revived the magic that wore off under Jose Mourinho, says Michael Ballack
text:
Sport New Chelsea boss Antonio Conte has revived the magic that wore off under Jose Mourinho, says Michael Ballack Ex-Blues midfielder reckons his old club have their sparkle back after the Special One led a dismal title defence last season Share It's hard to imagine Conte NOT winning the title in his debut season now (Photo: Chelsea FC via Getty)     
Michael Ballack believes Antonio Conte has taken Chelsea back to where they belong. 
The Blues legend admits he was surprised at the way his former club fell apart last season under Jose Mourinho. 
But he feels successor Conte has “found the key” to getting the old magic back as he warned Mourinho’s intense management style can only work for a limited time. 
Conte’s side are eight points clear at the top of the Premier League, and Ballack believes there are similarities between the two managers. 
The former Germany star, who had four years at Stamford Bridge, said: “The surprise was last year — that they were so bad. That they are top of the league now isn’t a great surprise. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Antonio Conte speaks after Costa returns with a goal Share this video Watch Next 
“It’s difficult to compare the coaches in general, because ­sometimes you’re at a club at the right time, at the right moment. 
“All I can say is I had a great time with Jose, a great time at Chelsea. He was a very special manager who found a very special axis with the players, in terms of communication. 
“It was always tense between the coach and the players. Mostly he was pushing us together as a group and was always at the front of the group, protecting us. He was our leader and we went for that away from the tactics and football circumstances. 
“We trained day-in, day-out and this is something when you work so long together you have to have a groove and create a good ­atmosphere. I think that’s so ­important these days if you want to work as a manager. Chelsea are loving life under new management (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
“And he did that. But sometimes it’s not easy when you have 20 egos, 20 individuals as players, sometimes one or two can create a bit of trouble because they’re not happy. 
“These days at Chelsea it looks as if it works, but last year it seems like it wasn’t the case — the players and the coach weren’t always going in the same direction. And that’s why I think it didn’t work and Conte now I think he has found that key. 
“Sometimes as a coach it’s difficult to do that over a long period. ­Sometimes you lose it a bit. Even if it’s just a few percentage and ­sometimes it is time to have a change and have your input at a new club. 
“A new challenge for yourself and the players. I think this is a totally natural process in a football team. 
“If you see he’s not good enough or this player isn’t good enough – it’s just sometimes small things aren’t like maybe what they were two years ago. Mourinho won three league titles in his two spells as Chelsea manager (Photo: Getty) 
“So that’s why also when you come back to a club where you were already successful, sometimes it’s questionable. With him it didn’t really work, especially at the end and they went different way. 
“But Conte is fresh, it’s simple football, clear football, very understandable football. He’s very competitive and when I talk to him it’s like Italian ­football, very organised, very disciplined and controlled.” 
Ballack is convinced Conte – who has made a start equally as impressive as Mourinho when he took over at Chelsea in 2004 – will build on the lead and win the title. 
He added: “The team is playing to their strengths, making very few mistakes, conceding not many goals. That’s the key if you want to win a title – to be solid.
